text: <@U0290H6FUAZ> has joined the channel

Hi, just looking at logging market books using bflw streaming. In the listener.py file the logger is defined at the top as a global variable. I am finding this a bit inflexible, for example when I want to log two races into separate files with different logger 'names'. Is there a better way to do this? I was hoping maybe to feed a pre-prepared logger into the listener when creating the listener object?

elements.text: Hi, just looking at logging market books using bflw streaming. In the listener.py file the logger is defined at the top as a global variable. I am finding this a bit inflexible, for example when I want to log two races into separate files with different logger 'names'. Is there a better way to do this? I was hoping maybe to feed a pre-prepared logger into the listener when creating the listener object?

text: Why are you dropping down to the listener level rather than dealing with the books from the queue?

elements.text: Why are you dropping down to the listener level rather than dealing with the books from the queue?

text: the logging is done at the listener level i think?

elements.text: the logging is done at the listener level i think?

text: Yeah but that is library level logging

elements.text: Yeah but that is library level logging

text: sorry not sure what that means. it's where the logger debug call is made so that is what determines where the messages are written to.

elements.text: sorry not sure what that means. it's where the logger debug call is made so that is what determines where the messages are written to.

text: i don't know how to regain flexibility over that without subclassing the listeners, adding in a logger argument and rewriting every function that includes 'logger' to be 'self.logger'

elements.text: i don't know how to regain flexibility over that without subclassing the listeners, adding in a logger argument and rewriting every function that includes 'logger' to be 'self.logger'

text: So that logging call is for debugging the raw messages that come through the steam

elements.text: So that logging call is for debugging the raw messages that come through the steam

text: agreed

elements.text: agreed

text: From a user perspective logging would go <https://github.com/liampauling/betfair/blob/6991a6a51363bae5fe5940f647b5cf7a4e7113cb/examples/examplestreaming.py#L74|here> and you wouldn’t touch the bflw library logging but then I am not sure what you are trying to do?

elements.text: From a user perspective logging would go
here
and you wouldn’t touch the bflw library logging but then I am not sure what you are trying to do?

text: OK, I guess I could do it from the queue instead. I suppose I felt like if it's already being logged via the listener then i shouldn't be doing it again as that's then logging twice

elements.text: OK, I guess I could do it from the queue instead. I suppose I felt like if it's already being logged via the listener then i shouldn't be doing it again as that's then logging twice

text: seems more efficient to only log once?

elements.text: seems more efficient to only log once?

text: or is the listener.py logging code only for printing to stdout, and should generally be turned off in prod?

elements.text: or is the listener.py logging code only for printing to stdout, and should generally be turned off in prod?

text: Unless you've set the log level to debug for betfairlightweight it's not being logged anyway

elements.text: Unless you've set the log level to debug for betfairlightweight it's not being logged anyway

text: There is also a <https://github.com/liampauling/betfair/blob/6991a6a51363bae5fe5940f647b5cf7a4e7113cb/betfairlightweight/streaming/listener.py#L95|flag> on the listener as well to completely remove the overhead, even though debug might be disabled there is a cost in sending a large dict to the debug call

elements.text: There is also a
flag
on the listener as well to completely remove the overhead, even though debug might be disabled there is a cost in sending a large dict to the debug call

text: But yeah don’t debug in prod

elements.text: But yeah don’t debug in prod

text: But not sure why you would be logging the raw updates anyway

elements.text: But not sure why you would be logging the raw updates anyway

text: what makes them raw?

elements.text: what makes them raw?

text: aren't they the same thing as what you'd get as the market_book.streaming_update

elements.text: aren't they the same thing as what you'd get as the market_book.streaming_update

text: Yeah, just the raw update from the stream, ie. delta update

elements.text: Yeah, just the raw update from the stream, ie. delta update

text: why would i not log it? is there something better to log?

elements.text: why would i not log it? is there something better to log?

text: Most record the raw streaming data to a file for backtesting later

elements.text: Most record the raw streaming data to a file for backtesting later

text: that's what I am doing right?

elements.text: that's what I am doing right?

text: i am getting confused :exploding_head:

elements.text: i am getting confused

text: what's the difference between logging the raw market book delta updates and logging the raw streaming data

elements.text: what's the difference between logging the raw market book delta updates and logging the raw streaming data

text: Sorry, technically the same just different terminology, I would say it’s better practice to save data like this to a file using open/write rather than the logging library as you have far more control

elements.text: Sorry, technically the same just different terminology, I would say it’s better practice to save data like this to a file using open/write rather than the logging library as you have far more control

text: Learning again :man-facepalming:. Id though the default would be False if its advisable to be off or am I thinking about it the wrong way round. Does anything need setting in flumine then. Its this just the raw stream logging, i.e. if listener_kwargs dict debug is false will the order logging continue ? currently  im not setting anything

elements.text: Learning again

. Id though the default would be False if its advisable to be off or am I thinking about it the wrong way round. Does anything need setting in flumine then. Its this just the raw stream logging, i.e. if listener_kwargs dict debug is false will the order logging continue ? currently  im not setting anything

text: Flumine sets this to false by default and does a few other things to be quicker :wink:

elements.text: Flumine sets this to false by default and does a few other things to be quicker

text: ok thanks for your help

text: perfect :raised_hands:

text: <@U029GL7QXMX> has joined the channel

root.text: Hi all, I have managed to collect some horse racing data (huge thanks to <@U4H19D1D2>’s flumine!) for the past month, and am trying to setup backtesting with flumine. I saw this backtest example <https://liampauling.github.io/flumine/quickstart#backtesting> passing one market/file (1.170212754?) to the flumine. I was trying to find a way to pass the entire folder of recorded data to flumine, but with no luck. Please could someone give me a pointer? Many thanks.

elements.text: Hi all, I have managed to collect some horse racing data (huge thanks to
’s flumine!) for the past month, and am trying to setup backtesting with flumine. I saw this backtest example

passing one market/file (1.170212754?) to the flumine. I was trying to find a way to pass the entire folder of recorded data to flumine, but with no luck. Please could someone give me a pointer? Many thanks.

text: Hi <@U012ZFYR19V> and <@UPMUFSGCR>, it took me a while to make the backtest_multi.py work for me, but so far it's looking great, so thanks very much! I needed to add "`freeze_support()`" to make it work, otherwise it throws an error. I am not able to plug in the bz2 files directly (I got error message like "`UnicodeDecodeError: 'charmap' codec can't decode byte 0x81 in position 41: character maps to <undefined>`"), so have to decompress them manually. Guess I am missing something. Please could you give me a pointer?

elements.text: Hi
and
, it took me a while to make the backtest_multi.py work for me, but so far it's looking great, so thanks very much! I needed to add "
freeze_support()
" to make it work, otherwise it throws an error. I am not able to plug in the bz2 files directly (I got error message like "
UnicodeDecodeError: 'charmap' codec can't decode byte 0x81 in position 41: character maps to <undefined>
"), so have to decompress them manually. Guess I am missing something. Please could you give me a pointer?

text: Did you make any changes to the script? It patches open with smart_open.open so it should be able to read the bz2 files directly

elements.text: Did you make any changes to the script? It patches open with smart_open.open so it should be able to read the bz2 files directly
